G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 because this action is brought for monetary damages that are within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville Division of the District Court Department under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the events giving rise to Plaintiff’s claims occurred at Defendant’s grocery store located in Somerville, Massachusetts.

_See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp.raw_text: _See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.,_ 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973).
_See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff, a business invitee, a duty to use reasonable care to maintain its premises in a safe condition and to warn of or eliminate risks of harm that were known or reasonably foreseeable.
_See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
_See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the duty of one who controls business premises toward patrons, using language that matches the proposition: a duty to use due care to keep premises reasonably safe and to warn of dangers not likely to be known to patrons but known or reasonably knowable to the defendant. Although the case ultimately finds no negligence on the facts, it clearly affirms the general Massachusetts rule on a business invitor’s duty to invitees, so it is proper authority for the stated proposition.
_See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp.relevant_excerpt: "1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. Rossley v. S. S. Kresge Co. 339 Mass. 654, 656. Coates v. First Natl. Stores Inc. 322 Mass, 563, 565. Vance v. Gould, 355 Mass. 104, 105."

_See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.raw_text: _See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.,_ 448 Mass. 780, 788 (2007).
_See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.proposition: Massachusetts law further establishes that a store owner must inspect and remedy hazardous conditions within a reasonable time.
_See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
_See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.support_reasoning: The court describes Massachusetts’ traditional premises-liability rule as requiring that a store owner maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition while being afforded a reasonable opportunity to discover and correct hazards before liability attaches. It further explains that liability arises only if the owner has actual or constructive notice of the dangerous condition for sufficient time to remedy it, which presupposes a duty to inspect and remedy hazards within a reasonable time. Although Sheehan adopts the mode-of-operation approach, it expressly reaffirms this traditional Massachusetts principle.
_See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.relevant_excerpt: Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property "in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk." Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). However, the law has afforded store owners a reasonable opportunity to discover and correct any hazards before liability attaches. … This court has thus held that premises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition.

_see Berube v. Economy Grocery Stores Co.raw_text: _see Berube v. Economy Grocery Stores Corp.,_ 315 Mass. 89, 93 (1943),
_see Berube v. Economy Grocery Stores Co.proposition: A property owner is liable where its failure to act caused a dangerous condition that foreseeably led to an injury, _see Berube v. Economy Grocery Stores Corp.,_ 315 Mass. 89, 93 (1943), which is precisely what occurred here.
_see Berube v. Economy Grocery Stores Co.case_name: Berube v. Economy Grocery Stores Corp.
_see Berube v. Economy Grocery Stores Co.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies premises-liability principles to a store owner: the defendant had a duty to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe and to warn of dangers it knew or should have known about, and liability was predicated on its failure to remove a dangerous condition (the squash on the floor) that foreseeably caused the plaintiff’s fall. The court holds that the jury could find the store negligent because the condition existed long enough and in such a way that the defendant, through reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it. That directly supports a proposition that a property owner is liable when its failure to act allows a dangerous condition to persist and cause injury.
_see Berube v. Economy Grocery Stores Co.relevant_excerpt: "[T]he defendant was bound to use due care to keep that portion of the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, and to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use by reason of a condition of the premises, which were not likely to be known to its patrons and of which the defendant knew or ought to have known. ... [T]he jury could have found that the mound of squash ... had been on the floor long enough to have been removed before the accident, and that it had remained on the floor until the time of the injury because of negligence of the defendant."

_See Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.,_ 389 M.raw_text: _See Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.,_ 389 Mass. 47, 57 (1983).
_See Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.,_ 389 M.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that a property owner may be held liable if an employee’s negligence, in the course of their duties, leads to harm.
_See Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.,_ 389 M.support_reasoning: Although this is a dissent focused on proximate causation, it proceeds on the premise—shared with the majority—that the college (a property owner) owed a duty of reasonable care to protect a student and could be found negligent based on failures in its security system and staff conduct. The dissent does not dispute that the defendants’ negligence, including actions and inactions of employees (e.g., campus security, supervision of guards), could create liability; it only argues the evidence did not sufficiently prove that such negligence caused the harm. Thus the case, as a whole, recognizes that a property owner may be liable when employees’ negligent performance of their duties leads to harm.
_See Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.,_ 389 M.relevant_excerpt: The next inquiry is whether, if the assailant was a lawful visitor, the jury could have found that he gained entrance to the plaintiff’s room due to the defendants’ negligence. I agree that the jury could have found that the system for locking the room door was inadequate due to the defendants’ negligence, but I do not agree that the jury could have found that entry into the room was gained by disengaging a lock. … In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury….

_See G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85._.proposition: Defendant’s negligent conduct was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, as recognized under Massachusetts law.

_O\u2019Brien v. Pearson,_ 449 Mass. 377.proposition: Plaintiff incurred damages as a result of Defendant’s failure to fulfill its legal obligations, including medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering, consistent with principles of damages as outlined in _O’Brien v. Pearson,_ 449 Mass. 377, 384 (2007).
_O\u2019Brien v. Pearson,_ 449 Mass. 377.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns damages for breach of fiduciary duty among close corporation shareholders and focuses narrowly on lost-profit, shareholder-type economic damages. It does not address or apply tort-style personal injury categories such as medical expenses, lost wages, or pain and suffering. The court’s damages discussion is about lost corporate profits and the plaintiff’s reasonable shareholder expectations, so using this case to support a proposition about medical and personal injury damages misstates its holding and context.
_O\u2019Brien v. Pearson,_ 449 Mass. 377.relevant_excerpt: “Recovery of lost profits, as with all compensatory damages, requires a showing that the claimed losses were proximately caused by the wrongful conduct of the defendant. … The question is whether the facts prove within a reasonable degree of certainty that the breach, i.e., the wrongful conduct of the defendants, caused O’Brien to suffer the damages he sought to establish. … We recently have considered the appropriate remedy for the freezeout of a minority shareholder… [which] should, to the extent possible, restore to the minority shareholder those benefits which [he] reasonably expected….”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Prejudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
